119th CONGRESS
1st SESSION

H.R. 2847

AN ACT
To amend the Public Health Service Act to modernize public health emergency reporting requirements and strengthen coordination between State and Federal health agencies.

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled,

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE.
This Act may be cited as the "Public Health Emergency Reporting Modernization Act of 2026".

SEC. 2. FINDINGS.
Congress finds the following:
(1) Timely and accurate reporting of public health emergencies is essential to protecting the health and safety of the American public.
(2) Current reporting requirements under section 247d of title 42, United States Code, require modernization to address emerging infectious diseases and bioterrorism threats.
(3) Enhanced coordination between State health departments and the Department of Health and Human Services will improve emergency response capabilities.

SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY REPORTING.
(a) IN GENERAL.—Section 247d of title 42, United States Code, is amended—
(1) by striking "shall report to the Secretary" and inserting "shall report electronically to the Secretary within 24 hours";
(2) in inserting after subsection (a) the following new subsection:
"(a-1) REAL-TIME REPORTING SYSTEM.—
"(1) The Secretary shall establish and maintain a secure, real-time electronic reporting system for public health emergencies.
"(2) State and local health departments shall use this system to report any suspected outbreak of a disease or condition that may constitute a public health emergency.
"(3) The system shall provide for the automatic notification of relevant Federal agencies, including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention."; and
(3) by striking subsection (b)(2) and inserting the following:
"(2) COORDINATION WITH STATES.—The Secretary shall coordinate with State health officers to ensure—
"(A) uniform reporting standards across all States;
"(B) interoperability of State and Federal reporting systems;
"(C) protection of individually identifiable health information in accordance with section 264 of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996; and
"(D) regular training and technical assistance for State health department personnel.".

SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO MEDICAID REPORTING.
Section 1396a(a) of title 42, United States Code, is amended—
(1) by redesignating paragraph (87) as paragraph (88); and
(2) by inserting after paragraph (86) the following new paragraph:
"(87) provide that the State shall report to the Secretary, in a form and manner specified by the Secretary, any public health emergency that affects the delivery of medical assistance under the State plan, including—
"(A) the nature and scope of the emergency;
"(B) the estimated number of individuals affected;
"(C) actions taken by the State to ensure continuity of care; and
"(D) any requests for Federal assistance or waivers.".

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE.
(a) IN GENERAL.—Except as provided in subsection (b), the amendments made by this Act shall take effect on the date that is 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act.
(b) ELECTRONIC REPORTING SYSTEM.—The electronic reporting system required under section 247d(a-1) of title 42, United States Code, as added by section 3, shall be operational not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act.
